text: Our general mindset is in two months, there's going to be a better model and it's going to blow away whatever the current set of limitations are. And we say this to developers too. If you're building and the product that you're building is kind of right on the edge of the capabilities of the models, keep going because you're doing something right. Give it another couple months and the models are going to be great, and suddenly the product that you have that just barely worked is really going to sing.
speaker: Kevin Weil
context: Lenny asks Kevin about what it's like working at the center of the AI revolution at OpenAI. Kevin explains their philosophy of 'model maximalism' - the idea that instead of building extensive workarounds for current model limitations, they focus on the fact that AI models improve dramatically every few months. He's advising both internal teams and external developers to push the boundaries of what's currently possible, knowing that upcoming model improvements will make products that barely work today perform exceptionally well in the near future.
text_ko: 우리의 기본 사고방식은 ‘두 달이면 더 나은 모델(model)이 나와서 지금의 제약들을 완전히 뛰어넘을 거다’예요. 개발자(developer)들에게도 그렇게 말해요. 지금 만들고 있는 제품(product)이 모델(model)의 역량(capabilities) 바로 경계에 걸쳐 있다면 계속 밀고 가라고 해요 — 그건 제대로 하고 있다는 신호예요. 두 달만 더 지나면 모델(model)이 훨씬 좋아지고, 지금 간신히 돌아가던 그 제품(product)이 갑자기 진짜 빛을 발할 거예요.
text_zh: 我们的基本想法是这样的，两个月后肯定会有更好的模型出来，直接把现在这些限制都给突破了。我们也跟开发者们这么说，如果你在做的产品刚好卡在模型能力的边缘上，那就继续干下去，说明你的方向是对的。再给两个月时间，模型会变得特别厉害，到时候你那个现在勉强能跑的产品，突然就会表现得特别棒。
text_es: Nuestra mentalidad en general es que en dos meses va a salir un modelo mejor que va a arrasar con todas las limitaciones que tenemos ahora. Y esto mismo les decimos a los desarrolladores. Si están construyendo algo y el producto que están haciendo está justo en el límite de lo que pueden hacer los modelos actuales, sigan adelante porque van por buen camino. Denle un par de meses más y los modelos van a estar buenísimos, y de repente ese producto que tenían que apenas funcionaba va a ser una joya.
key_sentence: Models will blow away current limitations; keep building if you're right on the edge.

text: Everywhere I've ever worked before this, you kind of know what technology you're building on, but that's not true at all with AI. Every two months, computers can do something they've never been able to do before and you need to completely think differently about what you're doing.
speaker: Kevin Weil
context: Lenny asks what's most different about working at OpenAI compared to Kevin's previous roles at traditional tech companies like Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook. Kevin explains that unlike conventional software development where the underlying technology stack remains relatively stable, AI development is fundamentally different because the core capabilities of the models evolve rapidly. This constant advancement in AI capabilities requires product teams to continuously rethink their approach and strategies.
text_ko: 지금까지 일했던 곳들은 보통 어떤 기술을 기반으로 하는지 어느 정도 알 수 있었어요. 그런데 인공지능(AI)은 전혀 그렇지 않아요. 두 달마다 컴퓨터가 이전에는 못하던 일을 해내니까 우리가 하는 일을 완전히 다르게 생각해야 해요.
text_zh: 我之前在别的公司工作的时候，基本上都清楚自己在用什么技术做事，但搞AI完全不是这么回事。每隔两个月，电脑就能做一些以前根本做不到的事情，你得完全换个思路重新考虑自己在干什么。
text_es: En todos los trabajos que he tenido antes de este, más o menos sabías con qué tecnología ibas a trabajar, pero con la IA eso no aplica para nada. Cada dos meses las computadoras pueden hacer algo que jamás habían podido hacer antes, y tienes que replantear completamente tu forma de enfocar lo que estás haciendo.
key_sentence: AI technology evolves rapidly; think differently about your projects every two months.

text: If you're building and the product that you're building is right on the edge of the capabilities of the models, keep going, because you're doing something right because you give it another couple months and the models are going to be great, and suddenly the product that you have that just barely worked is really going to sing.
speaker: Kevin Weil
context: Lenny asks about OpenAI's product philosophy and how they approach building products when the underlying AI technology is constantly improving. Kevin is explaining their 'model maximalism' approach - rather than building extensive workarounds for current AI limitations, they advise developers to build products that push current model capabilities to their limits. His point is that products struggling with today's models will excel as the models rapidly improve over the coming months.
text_ko: 만약 지금 만들고 있는 제품이 모델(models)의 성능 한계 바로 경계에 있다면, 계속 밀어붙이세요. 그건 잘하고 있다는 신호예요. 몇 달만 더 기다리면 모델들이 훨씬 좋아질 거고, 지금은 간신히 작동하던 제품도 갑자기 정말 빛을 발할 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你在做产品开发，而你的产品刚好卡在模型能力的边缘上，别停下来，继续干，因为你走对路了。再给几个月时间，模型会变得特别厉害，到时候你那个刚刚能跑起来的产品就真的要起飞了。
text_es: Si estás desarrollando algo y tu producto está justo en el límite de lo que pueden hacer los modelos actuales, sigue adelante, porque vas por buen camino. Dale un par de meses más y los modelos van a estar increíbles, y de repente ese producto tuyo que apenas funcionaba va a brillar de verdad.
key_sentence: Keep going if your product barely worked; models will soon really sing.

text: I think you're definitely going to live in a world where you have researchers built into every product team. And I don't even mean just at foundation model companies because I think the future... Actually, frankly one thing that I'm sort of surprised about about our industry in general is that there's not a greater use of fine-tuned models.
speaker: Kevin Weil
context: Lenny asks Kevin about how product teams might change in the future as AI becomes more prevalent. Kevin predicts that product teams across all companies, not just AI companies, will need to include researchers or machine learning engineers. He explains that the future will involve extensive use of fine-tuned models - AI models customized for specific use cases rather than using generic models. This will require teams to have the expertise to adapt and optimize models for their particular product needs.
text_ko: 저는 분명 앞으로 모든 제품팀에 연구자들이 들어와 있는 세상에서 살게 될 거라고 생각해요. 이게 파운데이션 모델(foundation model) 회사들에만 해당되는 얘기가 아니에요. 솔직히 말하면 업계 전반을 보면서 파인튜닝된 모델들(fine-tuned models)을 훨씬 더 많이 쓰고 있을 줄 알았는데, 그렇지 않은 점이 좀 놀라워요.
text_zh: 我觉得以后肯定会是这样，每个产品团队里都会配研究人员。而且我说的不只是那些做基础模型(foundation model)的公司，因为我觉得未来...说实话，咱们这个行业有一点让我挺意外的，就是微调模型(fine-tuned models)用得还是不够多。
text_es: Creo que definitivamente vas a vivir en un mundo donde tengas investigadores integrados en cada equipo de producto. Y no me refiero solo a las empresas de modelos base porque pienso que el futuro... La verdad, una cosa que me sorprende bastante de nuestra industria en general es que no se use más el fine-tuning de modelos.
key_sentence: Researchers will be built into every product team, enhancing fine-tuned models' use.

text: I think if you teach your kids to be curious, to be independent, to be self-confident, you teach them how to think, I don't know what the future holds, but I think that those are going to be skills that are going to be important in any configuration of the future.
speaker: Kevin Weil
context: Lenny asks Kevin, who has three children, what skills he's encouraging his kids to learn to prepare for an AI-dominated future. A community member jokingly worried that by 2036, kids might need to compete for spots in roofing or plumbing programs as AI takes over other jobs. Kevin responds with a thoughtful perspective that instead of trying to predict specific career paths, parents should focus on developing fundamental human capabilities that will remain valuable regardless of how technology evolves.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 아이들에게 호기심을 갖게 하고, 자립심과 자신감을 길러주면 생각하는 법을 가르치는 거예요. 미래가 어떻게 될지는 모르겠지만, 그런 역량(skills)은 미래가 어떤 모습이든 중요해질 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得啊，如果你教孩子保持好奇心，培养他们独立自主，让他们有自信，最重要的是教会他们怎么思考，虽然说未来会怎样谁也说不准，但我相信这些能力在任何情况下都会很重要的。
text_es: Yo creo que si les enseñas a tus hijos a ser curiosos, a ser independientes, a tener confianza en sí mismos, si les enseñas a pensar por cuenta propia, no sé qué nos depare el futuro, pero estoy seguro de que esas van a ser habilidades clave en cualquier escenario que se presente.
key_sentence: Teaching curiosity and independence prepares kids for any configuration of the future.

text: It fundamentally disappoints me that this doesn't exist in the world today because the world would be a better place if we'd been able to ship that product. We tried to launch a new blockchain. It was a basket of currencies originally. It was integration into WhatsApp and Messenger. I would be able to send you 50 cents in WhatsApp for free. It should exist.
speaker: Kevin Weil
context: Lenny asks Kevin about Libra, the cryptocurrency project he worked on at Facebook that ultimately failed. Kevin explains that Libra was designed to solve real problems like expensive international remittances, where people pay 20% fees to send money to family in other countries. The project aimed to enable instant, free money transfers through WhatsApp and Messenger using a new blockchain and basket of currencies. Kevin expresses genuine disappointment that this product never launched because he believes it would have made the world better by solving these costly, inefficient payment problems.
text_ko: 이런 게 세상에 없다는 게 정말 아쉽고, 만약 이 제품이 출시됐다면 세상이 더 나아졌을 거라고 생각해요. 저희는 새로운 블록체인(blockchain)을 출시하려고 했었어요. 처음에는 여러 통화의 집합체였고, WhatsApp과 Messenger에 통합하는 방식이었죠. 그래서 제가 당신에게 WhatsApp으로 50센트를 무료로 보낼 수 있었을 거예요. 이건 꼭 존재해야 해요.
text_zh: 说实话，这个产品到现在都没能做出来，我真的挺失望的，因为如果我们当时能把这个产品推出来，世界肯定会变得更好。我们试过推出一个新的区块链(blockchain)，最初是一篮子货币的概念，要整合到WhatsApp和Messenger里面。这样我就能在WhatsApp里免费给你转个50美分什么的。这个功能真的应该存在的。
text_es: Me decepciona profundamente que esto no exista hoy en día porque el mundo sería un lugar mejor si hubiéramos logrado sacar ese producto al mercado. Tratamos de lanzar una nueva blockchain. Originalmente era una canasta de monedas. Era integración con WhatsApp y Messenger. Yo te podría enviar 50 centavos por WhatsApp gratis. Esto debería existir.
key_sentence: It fundamentally disappoints me that we couldn't ship that product; the world needs it.
